title: Forces, Motion, and Simple Machines

vocab.kid_friendly_definition: A push or pull that can make objects move, stop, or change direction.
When an object moves from one place to another.
A tool that makes work easier by changing the direction or amount of force needed.
A simple machine that uses a bar that turns on a fulcrum to lift or move things.
A slanted surface (like a ramp) that helps move objects up or down with less force.
A wheel with a rope that changes the direction of a pull to lift things.
A force that slows or stops motion when two surfaces rub.
The point where a lever turns or pivots.
A simple machine that helps things roll and reduces friction.
A simple machine with a sharp edge that can cut or split things.
An inclined plane wrapped around a cylinder that holds things together or lifts.
Equal forces that act in opposite directions and do not change motion.
The force that pulls objects down toward Earth.
The way objects keep doing what they're already doing unless a force acts on them.

teachingNotes: Use hands-on experiments with ramps, levers, and pulleys. Let students test different forces and observe motion. Connect to playground equipment.

A ramp is an example of an inclined plane.
Pushing and pulling are both types of forces.
